articles.headline: How Tech Is Helping Poor People Get Government Aid
articles.snippet: Even as the government expanded aid programs, many people faced barriers to using them. That problem is now being addressed with apps and streamlined websites.
articles.abstract: Even as the government expanded aid programs, many people faced barriers to using them. That problem is now being addressed with apps and streamlined websites.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In making his case that safety net programs should be easier to use, Jimmy Chen, a tech entrepreneur, recalled visiting a welfare office where people on food stamps endured long waits to submit routine paperwork.

articles.headline: Ally, Member or Partner? NATO’s Long Dilemma Over Ukraine.
articles.snippet: NATO promised Ukraine full membership in 2008, but without explaining how or when. Putin sees that promise as an ongoing threat to Russia.
articles.abstract: NATO promised Ukraine full membership in 2008, but without explaining how or when. Putin sees that promise as an ongoing threat to Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Ukraine presents NATO with a dilemma many years in the making — one the alliance, itself, helped create.

articles.headline: U.S. Threat to Squeeze Russia’s Economy Is a Tactic With a Mixed Record
articles.snippet: Sanctions, like aiming to cut oil exports, could also hurt European allies. “It’s a limited toolbox,” one expert said.
articles.abstract: Sanctions, like aiming to cut oil exports, could also hurt European allies. “It’s a limited toolbox,” one expert said.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Russian soldiers crossed into Ukraine and seized Crimea in 2014, the Obama administration responded with a slate of economic penalties that ultimately imposed sanctions on hundreds of Russian officials and businesses and restricted investments and trade in the nation’s crucial finance, oil and military sectors.

articles.headline: Where the Despairing Log On, and Learn Ways to Die
articles.snippet: It has the trappings of popular social media, a young audience and explicit content on suicide that other sites don’t allow. It is linked to a long line of lives cut short.
articles.abstract: It has the trappings of popular social media, a young audience and explicit content on suicide that other sites don’t allow. It is linked to a long line of lives cut short.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has the trappings of popular social media, a young audience and explicit content on suicide that other sites don’t allow. It is linked to a long line of lives cut short.
articles.byline: By Megan Twohey and Gabriel J.X. Dance

articles.headline: Ukraine Commanders Say a Russian Invasion Would Overwhelm Them
articles.snippet: If Russia opts for an invasion, Ukraine’s generals say, they would have no hope of repelling it without a major infusion of military help from the West.
articles.abstract: If Russia opts for an invasion, Ukraine’s generals say, they would have no hope of repelling it without a major infusion of military help from the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — On the 30th anniversary of the founding of Ukraine’s armed forces, President Volodymyr Zelensky donned a helmet and flak jacket to tour the trenches this week and announced with great fanfare the delivery of new tanks, armored vehicles and ships to frontline units engaged in fighting Russian forces and Kremlin-backed separatists.

articles.headline: How the Supply Chain Upheaval Became a Life-or-Death Threat
articles.snippet: A maker of medical devices can’t keep up with customer demand as the shortage of computer chips puts it in competition with bigger companies with more clout.
articles.abstract: A maker of medical devices can’t keep up with customer demand as the shortage of computer chips puts it in competition with bigger companies with more clout.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of this year, Joseph Norwood’s next breath was locked in a zero-sum competition with people eager to upgrade their iPhones.

articles.headline: China Evergrande Defaults on Its Debt. Now What?
articles.snippet: A ratings agency’s declaration confirmed what investors had already suspected, but they now must wait on a restructuring plan overseen by the firm hand of Beijing.
articles.abstract: A ratings agency’s declaration confirmed what investors had already suspected, but they now must wait on a restructuring plan overseen by the firm hand of Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For weeks, global markets have been watching the struggles of China Evergrande, a teetering real estate giant weighed down by $300 billion or more in obligations that just barely seemed able to make its required payments to global investors.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

articles.headline: Europe Pushes New Rules Turning Gig Workers Into Employees
articles.snippet: A proposal with widespread political support would entitle drivers and couriers for companies like Uber to a minimum wage and legal protections.
articles.abstract: A proposal with widespread political support would entitle drivers and couriers for companies like Uber to a minimum wage and legal protections.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In one of the biggest challenges yet to the labor practices at popular ride-hailing and food-delivery services, the European Commission took a major step on Thursday toward requiring companies like Uber to consider their drivers and couriers as employees entitled to a minimum wage and legal protections.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Elian Peltier

articles.headline: Birds Aren’t Real, or Are They? Inside a Gen Z Conspiracy Theory.
articles.snippet: Peter McIndoe, the 23-year-old creator of the viral Birds Aren’t Real movement, is ready to reveal what the effort is really about.
articles.abstract: Peter McIndoe, the 23-year-old creator of the viral Birds Aren’t Real movement, is ready to reveal what the effort is really about.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Pittsburgh, Memphis and Los Angeles, massive billboards recently popped up declaring, “Birds Aren’t Real.”

articles.headline: How Nursing Homes’ Worst Offenses Are Hidden From the Public
articles.snippet: Thousands of problems identified by state inspectors were never publicly disclosed because of a secretive appeals process, a New York Times investigation found.
articles.abstract: Thousands of problems identified by state inspectors were never publicly disclosed because of a secretive appeals process, a New York Times investigation found.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Robert Gebeloff, Katie Thomas and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
